questions.question: In which year did India raise the question of racism in the UN for the first time?
Why was the United Nations established?
questions.answer: To ensure peace and security at the international level after the destruction caused by the Second World War.

questions.question: Why did the League of Nations fail?
questions.answer: It failed because it could not stop the Second World War from happening.

questions.question: What is the 'Atlantic Treaty'?
questions.answer: A treaty signed on 14th August 1941 between Churchill and Roosevelt to set up a mechanism for international security.

questions.question: List the six main organs of the United Nations.
questions.answer: General Assembly, Security Council, Economic and Social Council, International Court of Justice, Trusteeship Council, Secretariat.

questions.question: What is the status of member nations in the General Assembly?
questions.answer: All member nations have the same status; there is no discrimination based on size or power.

questions.question: What does the General Assembly do?
questions.answer: It discusses global issues, passes resolutions, elects non-permanent members of the Security Council, and passes the annual budget.

questions.question: What is the 'Veto power'?
questions.answer: The power of the five permanent members of the Security Council to give a negative vote, which stops a decision from being taken.

questions.question: What is the main responsibility of the Security Council?
questions.answer: To maintain international peace and security.

questions.question: What is the function of the Economic and Social Council?
questions.answer: To coordinate the economic and social policies of the United Nations.

questions.question: Who is the chief of the Secretariat?
questions.answer: The Secretary General.

questions.question: What is the role of the International Court of Justice?
questions.answer: To settle disputes between member nations and interpret international law authentically.

questions.question: What does the International Criminal Court do?
questions.answer: It prosecutes individuals for international crimes like genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes.

questions.question: Why has the work of the Trusteeship Council ended?
questions.answer: Because there are no trust territories left to administer; the last one, Palau, became independent in 1994.

questions.question: What is the role of UN Peacekeeping Forces?
questions.answer: To create favourable circumstances for permanent peace in strife-torn areas and ensure security.

questions.question: What are 'Specialised Agencies'?
questions.answer: Affiliated organisations working in specific areas (like health, labour, agriculture) to help different nations.

questions.question: Give the full form of WHO and its function.
questions.answer: World Health Organisation; it deals with global health issues.

questions.question: Give the full form of FAO.
questions.answer: Food and Agriculture Organisation.

questions.question: Give the full form of IMF.
questions.answer: International Monetary Fund.

questions.question: How has India contributed to the UN?
questions.answer: India has raised issues like racism and decolonisation, and has always sent troops for peacekeeping missions, including an all-woman force.

questions.question: What are the official languages of the UN?
questions.answer: English, French, Russian, Spanish, Chinese, and Arabic.

questions.question: Explain the principles of the United Nations.
questions.answer: The principles include: 1. All member nations have the same status without discrimination. 2. Members must respect the freedom and geographical unity of others. 3. International disputes must be solved peacefully.

questions.question: Describe the functions of the United Nations Security Council.
questions.answer: Its main responsibility is maintaining international peace. It can suggest resolving conflicts peacefully, impose economic sanctions, or take military action against aggressors. It prepares arms control policies and participates in appointing judges to the ICJ and the Secretary General.

questions.question: What are the functions of the Economic and Social Council?
questions.answer: It discusses global issues like poverty, unemployment, and inequality. It addresses women's empowerment, human rights, and health. It promotes cultural and educational cooperation and coordinates the work of affiliated organisations.

questions.question: Write about the Millennium Development Goals.
questions.answer: Decided in 2000, these goals include eliminating poverty and hunger, providing primary education, empowering women, reducing infant mortality, improving maternal health, fighting diseases like AIDS and malaria, and protecting the environment.

questions.question: How does the United Nations work towards the preservation of peace?
questions.answer: The UN aims to settle conflicts peacefully. It appoints intermediaries, uses legal procedures, or appoints arbitrators. If needed, it uses military means. It works to prevent violence in strife-torn areas, helps restore normalcy, starts schools, and creates awareness about human rights.
